awd_titl_txt: Symmetry, Geometry, and Topology of Quantum Many-Body States for Quantum Computation
awd_abstract_narration:
Information processing devices, like computers, have become ubiquitous and indispensable in modern life. A new promising paradigm, called quantum information processing (QIP), takes advantage of microscopic quantum variables (such as spins of electrons) to encode information. Counterintuitive quantum effects, such as superposition and quantum correlation or entanglement, enable us to process information with shades of gray, as compared with conventional black-or-white (so-called 0-or-1) logic, and so to attain drastic improvements over conventional devices. However, there are two major challenges to this paradigm. One is to figure out how to scale up further QIP devices, building on several current experimental platforms made of dozens of quantum bits. The other is to identify the information processing tasks for which QIP devices surpass conventional computers. The goal of this project is to address these key issues from the perspective of quantum many-body theory of macroscopic systems. It is advantageous, for example, to recognize that superconductivity and magnetism are quantum many-body phenomena that can be viewed and interpreted using quantum information concepts. In particular, it has been recently discovered that strongly frustrated quantum spin systems which manifest certain symmetries and topological phenomena might function as a quantum computer. Through this concrete example, the project seeks a deep connection between macroscopic quantum orders and quantum advantage in computation and simulation, by analyzing the important roles of symmetry, geometry, and topology. This research will also contribute to the knowledge base of quantum information science and to the training of future scientists in a highly interdisciplinary field. 

A fundamental interplay between entanglement and measurement lies at the heart of quantum information science. While the complexity of entanglement represents a uniquely quantum resource, its characteristic nonclassical features only reveal themselves through measurement. From Bell's inequality to recent quantum simulations of the so-called boson-sampling problem, landmark results of quantum information science have all relied upon balancing these two contrasting ingredients to practical effect. The framework of measurement-based quantum computation (MBQC) is convenient to study such an interplay and to analyze the origin of quantum speed-up in computation. Recently, it has been recognized that certain macroscopic entanglement, which would be naturally found in quantum spin liquid phases of frustrated quantum spin systems called symmetry-protected topological orders (SPTO), is capable of becoming a resource for MBQC. The project takes advantage of this unique, concrete connection between macroscopic quantum orders and computational complexity, to answer a key question "How do symmetry, geometry, and topology embodied in SPTO empower quantum computation and simulation?" Considering different lattice geometries and corresponding sublattice symmetries, the project will develop the classification of SPTO and analyze the associated structure of quantum cellular automata. These characterizations establish a direct route to quantum advantage using the order parameters of SPTO for certain short-depth quantum circuits. The approach would be effective to tackle two key challenges in the era of noisy intermediate-scale quantum technology, in that the natural structure of SPTO is explored to realize robust macroscopic entanglement with well-scalable control as well as complex computation and simulation beyond possible classical simulation. Broadly, the project cross-fertilizes two research fields, quantum information science and quantum many-body physics, timely at the coming age of quantum simulation when quantum many-body physics suggests many problems which quantum computers should be more efficient to solve than conventional computers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Information processing devices, like computers, have become ubiquitous and indispensable in our modern life as information society. A new promising paradigm, called quantum information processing (QIP), uses microscopic quantum states to encode information, and harnesses counterintuitive quantum effects such as superposition and quantum correlation called entanglement to attain drastic improvements over conventional devices. As the concepts from QIP are disseminated through quantum many-body physics recently, it gets clearer that nature handles quantum information better than we have imagined when it materializes various exotic macroscopic physical phenomena useful in our science and technology. This project continues to research how effectively the intrinsic complexity of quantum many-body systems can be harnessed for the advancement and scaling-up of QIP. Strongly-correlated quantum many-body systems, like certain frustrated quantum magnets called recently symmetry-protected topological orders (SPTO), are explored because entanglement available in the ground state of such systems potentially enables large-scale QIP. This theoretical project has contributed to cross-fertilize QIP and quantum many-body physics at their newly intersecting frontiers. 

The first major outcome is a discovery that topologically constrained correlations of a wide range of 1D SPTO ground states are useful not only to define quantum advantageous strategies for a certain Bell-type nonlocal game, but also to prove unconditional exponential computational advantage of short-depth quantum circuits over classical counterparts. This quantum advantage is indeed witnessed via measuring string order parameters, which characterize a macroscopic topological property of SPTO. This is timely as it adds values to near-term experiments of quantum simulation to prepare and detect SPTO. Second, PI's collaborative team implements its proof-of-principle experiment using the 6-qubit cluster state prepared on a gate-based ion-trap quantum computer at the University of Maryland. It is fruitful to scrutinize quantum advantageous conditions of Bell-type nonlocal games, by including additional classical communication as modeling of limited classical computation. The team derives the hierarchy of the classical bounds which limit the success probabilities of general depth-d classical circuits, and observes that the typical NISQ device is close to achieve unconditional quantum advantage against depth-1 classical circuits. The third major outcome is a research on adaptive measurement-based quantum computation for Boolean functions. In order to demonstrate further computational advantages using short-depth quantum circuits in an NISQ-friendly manner, PI tries to enhance their computational power using adapted choices of measurement bases conditioned on prior measurement outcomes. As computing Boolean functions is a widely studied computational task in both quantum and classical computation, certain quantum advantages can be proven unconditionally, extending the non-adaptive cases studied previously. In particular, it is shown that the adaptation is powerful enough to enable even an exponential reduction in the size of qubit registers for certain nonlinear Boolean functions. Overall, the project has taken advantage of a concrete connection between macroscopic quantum orders and quantum complexity, to approach the key issues about scalability and non-classical complexity in quantum computation and simulation. 

The research contributes to the knowledge base of quantum information science, and to the training of future scientists in this highly interdisciplinary field. Graduate students have been supported by this award, and one of them completed a Ph.D degree with distinction. The students were involved in all aspects of the project, including education, research, and the dissemination of results. The project broadens the current research spectrum of the NSF-funded Center for Quantum Information and Control (CQuIC) significantly towards the interface with quantum many-body physics. Video conferencing is used to allow participation of CQuIC partners in the regular activities of CQuIC, including weekly group meetings and research seminars. Students and senior personnel at CQuIC actively participate in the Southwest Quantum Information Technology (SQuInT) network, including the annual workshop. During its 25-year history, SQuInT has provided a vibrant avenue for exchange of ideas and results in QIP. PI works as its Chief Organizer over recent 8 years, and strives for nurturing the next generations of quantum information scientists.
